table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {SuD:v:0} means both "be green" and "take a risk". Also, Starfleet "redshirts" are infamous for dying.

table.name: mem
table.column: When can I return to my room?

table.name: mem
table.column: Since {tera'nganpu':n@@tera'ngan:n, -pu':n} is plural, and {'e':n:pro} is singular, there should be a prefix {lu-:v} on {tIv:v} if this sentence had been used in a formal situation. See the note under {lu-:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: I can't see well from here.

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence literally means "their heads are hitting themselves, Klingon warriors". Because of the strange grammar, many people consider this sentence to be in error.

table.name: mem
table.column: Two Federation crewmen arrive on Kronos.

table.name: mem
table.column: A prisoner says to the guard...

table.name: mem
table.column: Get that piece of junk out of here!

table.name: mem
table.column: This was spoken by Kruge to Valkris. The reason that he used {lI':v:2} while she used {lab:v} seems to be because they're on opposite ends of the transmission, but it's not exactly clear when each verb would be the right one to use.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a command given to a data transceiving device ({HablI':n}).

The subtitle says "Ready to transmit", which was the original English line spoken by the actress playing Valkris. However, the Klingon is phrased as a command, so "Prepare to transmit" is a better translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence was one of the most significant in the development of the Klingon language. It was originally supposed to mean "I told you, engines only." It was changed in the subtitles to say "I wanted prisoners." This led to the invention of the plural suffix for beings {-pu':n}, the accomplishment suffix {-ta':v}, the verb {neH:v} and the idea of clipped Klingon which was needed to explain its lack of any prefix, the rule that the second verb in a sentence-as-object construction never takes an aspect suffix, as well as a change in the meaning of the verb {ma':v} to mean "accommodate" (its original meaning being assigned to the new verb {ja':v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: I have purchased the Genesis data.
This was dubbed over the already-filmed line spoken in English, which was "I have obtained the Genesis data." The English subtitle was changed to say "I have purchased the Genesis data."

table.name: mem
table.column: One certainly finds it useful for the mission.
The subtitle says "You will find it useful", which was the original English line filmed.

table.name: mem
table.column: Kill one of them. I don't care which.

table.name: mem
table.column: cha'maH vagh vatlhvI' Hong, QIt yIghoS.

table.name: mem
table.column: DIvI' Se' wI'IjtaHvIS DaH ngoqDe' wIHevta'.
We've just received an encoded message on the Federation frequency.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: We have a target in sight.

table.name: mem
table.column: Hevetlh wIghoSchugh, veH tIn wI'el maH'e'.
That course will take us into the Barrier as well.

table.name: mem
table.column: jonlu'meH wo'maj pop tIn law' Hoch tIn puS.
Our Empire's highest bounty has been placed on his head.
[1] {Star Trek V deleted scene:src}, [2] {HQ 8.4, p.12, Dec. 1999:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: loDHom jIHDI' qIrq qun vIqImchoH. ghotvam Ho'lu'... 'ej muSlu'.
I've followed his history since I was a boy. A man to admire... and hate.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not delay. Alter your course now.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: I need a target that fights back.

table.name: mem
table.column: This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: (It is) a probe of ancient origin.

table.name: mem
table.column: The prefix should have been {wI-:v} instead of {ma-:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Starship Enterprise has been dispatched to Nimbus III.

table.name: mem
table.column: qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.
You would be the greatest warrior in the galaxy.

table.name: mem
table.column: The line was originally supposed to have been {wIqIpmeH Qatlh'a'?:sen@@wI-:v, qIp:v, -meH:v, Qatlh:v, -'a':v} Either way, the grammar of this sentence is strange, as it means "It is being difficult in order (for us) to hit it."

table.name: mem
table.column: {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: I've always wanted to engage a Federation ship.

table.name: mem
table.column: vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.
Shooting space garbage is no test of a warrior's mettle.

This is a backfit for the sentence, {vaj toDDujDaj ngeHbej DIvI'.@@vaj:adv, toDDuj:n, -Daj:n, ngeH:v, -bej:v, DIvI':n} "That means the Federation will be sending a rescue ship of its own." Both sentences were spoken by Captain Klaa in {Star Trek V:src}.
The original line was to have been {logh veQDaq bachchugh, yoH 'e' toblaHbe' SuvwI'.@@logh:n, veQ:n, -Daq:n, bach:v, -chugh:v, yoH:v, 'e':n, tob:v, -laH:v, -be':v, SuvwI':n}

table.name: mem
table.column: There will be no peace as long as Kirk lives.
[1] {Star Trek V deleted scene:src}, [2] {HQ 8.4, p.12, Dec. 1999:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: We are receiving a priority message from Operations Command.

This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}. The sentence in which this appeared was actually written with hyphens, like this: {HoD, yo'-SeH yaH-nIv-vo' potlh De' wI-Hev-taH:sen:nolink}, with a newline between {potlh:sen:nolink} and {De':sen:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {Star Trek V deleted scene:src}, [2] {HQ 8.4, p.13, Dec. 1999:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The subtitle actually says "Bear on Enterprise."

table.name: mem
table.column: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

table.name: mem
table.column: Attack or be slaves in their world!

table.name: mem
table.column: Attack them now, while we still can!

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the novelisation of {Star Trek VI:src}, this is an idiom which is smugglers' slang for wishing someone good luck in avoiding border officials.

table.name: mem
table.column: You don't seem to understand our situation.

table.name: mem
table.column: notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.
War is obsolete, as we are in danger of becoming.
The first part of this sentence, {notlh veS:sen:nolink}, appears on {KGT p.47:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: What's she doing? (Why is she going there?)

Here, "she" refers to the Enterprise ({'entepray':n:name}). Chang ({cheng:n:name}) was expressing puzzlement about the movement of the Enterprise.
The subtitle was "What's she doing?" but a more literal translation is "Why is she going there?"

table.name: mem
table.column: I am here to help you.
This literally means "I can be helpful. I'm traveling on a mission."
This was a lip-match for {DevwI' ghaH 'Iv'e'?@@DevwI':n, ghaH:n, 'Iv:ques:1h, -'e':n:suff} "Who is the leader?"

table.name: mem
table.column: ghach jIvvo' naH. DaH pIghvamDaq So''eghtaH.
There is a criminal hiding in these ruins.
The first half of this sentence was a lip-match for the beginning of {'ej jIHvo' nIHDI' jIbup:sen@@'ej:conj, jIH:n:1h, -vo':n, nIH:v, -DI':v, jI-:v, bup:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Qob lIb bam SoH chuDlI' je.
You and your people are in danger.

The expected prefix on {bam:v} is {bo-:v:pref}, since the subject is plural and second-person. However, occasionally and under certain circumstances, in a sentence with a compound second- and third-person subject, a non-prefixed verb is used. There is scant evidence that this usage is becoming more widespread in casual speech, and perhaps Uhura was speaking informally or idiomatically. This sentence shouldn't be taken as textbook Klingon, but might be an example of colloquial Klingon.[2]
Possibly {bo-:v:pref} was mixed up with {lI-:v:pref} during filming or editing, which forced {lIb:v} to be created.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Federation controls the Genesis Device.
This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: qa'vam yuQ Quv DaghojmeH Duyma'vaD yIjatlh.
To learn the Genesis Planet's coordinates, speak to our agent.
This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was the name of a documentary on the {Star Trek V Special Edition:src} second disc, in which Spice Williams ({vIqSIS:n:name}) and Todd Bryant ({tlha'a:n:name}) are interviewed about their experiences working on the movie.
[1] {Star Trek V Special Edition - That Klingon Couple:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The subtitle actually said {Somraw'Du':sen:nolink}, but this is a typo.
[1] {Star Trek V Special Edition - That Klingon Couple:src}

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the {HoD:n} of a starship named {'entepray':n:name}.
In Klingon, titles generally go after the name.
The name {'archer:n:name,nolink} has been heard spoken in Klingon, but has not appeared in written canon.

table.name: mem
table.column: Captain Archer and his crew are honorable people.

table.name: mem
table.column: Let them continue on their way.

table.name: mem
table.column: I have nothing to say to you, human.

table.name: mem
table.column: I demand to see the magistrate!

table.name: mem
table.column: What do you want with me?

This literally means "Why do you (plural) want me?"
To address a single person, say {qatlh choneH?:sen@@qatlh:ques, cho-:v, neH:v}

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also mean "Secure her!" or "Secure it!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "aim weapons on this section".

table.name: mem
table.column: ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh pa' DaqHomvetlh wovDaq HInej.
Then Kahless pointed to a star in the sky and said, "Look for me there, on that point of light."
This is part of the Story of the Promise, which tells of the departure (and prophesies the return) of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.

The Klingon text comes from an inscription seen on one of the {DSC:src} trailers, while the English translation is from {TNG - Rightful Heir:src}.
Set photos show that this sentence is preceded by {Suto'vo'qor vIjaH 'ach 'opleS jIchegh 'e' vIlay'.:sen@@Suto'vo'qor:n, vI-:v, jaH:v, 'ach:conj, 'opleS:n, jI-:v, chegh:v, 'e':n, vI-:v, lay':v}

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon translation was done by {Qov:n:name}. The English comes from the subtitles, with punctuation edited for clarity.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "We are Klingon, may it continue". The English subtitles render this as "Remain Klingon!"

The line was deliberately translated this way as it was believed that audiences would recognise the embedded {tlhIngan maH!:sen:nolink}
This can also be interpreted as {tlhIngan maHtaHjaj!:sen@@tlhIngan:n, maH:n:1h, -taH:v, -jaj:v}, "May we continue to be Klingon". This technically violates the rule that a Type 7 suffix cannot be used with {-jaj:v} (see note under that entry), but this rule was later explained to have exceptions that would've made this sentence acceptable.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
These lines were not given a name within the show, but some have referred to it online as "the Kahless prayer" or "the prayer to Kahless".
Even though the line spoken by {tIquvma:n:name} means "Give me light to go", it was still subtitled in English as "Give us light to see". This is probably a production error.
[1] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}, [2] {DSC - Despite Yourself:src}, [3] {DSC - The Wolf Inside:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of literary style.

table.name: mem
table.column: Spoken by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} to {qortar:n:name} in the {paq'batlh:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of literary style.

table.name: mem
table.column: Kahless broke Molor's sword in half.

table.name: mem
table.column: This manuscript is a main source in reconstructing classic Klingon opera.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the first book of the {paq'batlh:n}, in which {qeylIS:n} fights his brother {moratlh:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the second book of the {paq'batlh:n}, in which {qeylIS:n} enters {ghe'tor:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the third (and final) book of the {paq'batlh:n}, in which {qeylIS:n} defeats {molor:n} and enters {Suto'vo'qor:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: You need no one but yourselves!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of literary style.
This is written as "Qich'lut" in the book. It is in a form of {no' Hol:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was the name of an ancient city on Earth, the capital of the Akkadian Empire.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a borrowing from Federation Standard, so it isn't {'aqaD:n} plus {ngan:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the actress who plays {lurSa':n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {DoyIchlan:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is simply the Klingon pronunciation of the name of a specific tree found on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: One of the designers of the {BoP:src} poster. See {nIylo roDIS:n:name}.
▶ {lu'oghta' nIylo roDIS bIl jo'rIj je:sen:nolink} "Designed By: Nilo Rodis & Bill George"

table.name: mem
table.column: Both this term and {Hanghuq:n:place} are used. Klingons are very confused by this.[1]
"Chosŏn" is the name used for (unified) Korea in North Korea and by ethnic Koreans living in China and Japan.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the name of several disused Terran currencies.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the Terran retelling of {Hamlet:src}, the titular character is the prince of this country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: Its capital city is {berlIn:n}. Another large city is {Hamburgh:n}. The {qepHom'a':n} takes place in {Sarbruqen:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the Klingon spelling for the company name.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an animal from Terran mythology with the body of a lion and the wings of an eagle.

The definition uses the spelling from Lewis Carroll's "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland", because it was requested to translate that book, but this is more commonly spelled as "griffin" (or sometimes "griffon") in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city on the river {Sen:n} in the {noghmanDIy:n} region of {vIraS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the actress who plays {be'etor:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a Terran city located in {DoyIchlan:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Hanguk" is the name used for (unified) Korea in South Korea.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the actor who played Kor (see {qor:n:name}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a loanword from {DIvI' Hol:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a state located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}. It should not be confused with {SaQatvelo':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: At the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, MO said that he deliberately chose the Cantonese pronunciation for China rather than the Mandarin one, because the latter would have ended in {wo':n}, and he didn't think Klingons would like to call an Earth country by their word for "empire".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the colloquial name for {Sol vagh:n@@Sol:n, vagh:n:1,num}, a planet in the {Sol:n} system.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {'Inglan:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a city located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on Earth.
The Las Vegas Hilton hotel was the site of a themed attraction called Star Trek The Experience. The name of the city appeared in Klingon in the invitation to the grand opening.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a commune and city on the river {Sen:n} in the {noghmanDIy:n} region of {vIraS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a person from Earth history.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just borrowed in from Federation Standard. There is no native Klingon equivalent.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a loanword from Federation Standard, and refers to a resistance movement operating in the Demilitarized Zone between Federation and Cardassian space.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the colloquial name for {Sol loS:n@@Sol:n, loS:n:1,num}, a planet in the {Sol:n} system.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {raSya':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a person from Earth history.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what a Klingon would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a region spanning the border between {qa'naDa':n} and {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} with a famous {bIQ notron:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: One of the designers of the {BoP:src} poster. See {bIl jo'rIj:n:name}.
▶ {lu'oghta' nIylo roDIS bIl jo'rIj je:sen:nolink} "Designed By: Nilo Rodis & Bill George"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {vIraS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a borrowed word for a Terran food. It comes in different shapes, and while there are no official names for these, Klingons have informally described various forms of pasta as {mIv:n:1} (shell-shaped), {SIrgh:n} (spaghetti), {bo:n} (penne), and so on.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {cheSqa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food. To Klingons, pizzas are apparently a kind of {chab:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a place name in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a state located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a loanword for a Terran animal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a loanword for a Terran plant.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This is a province of {qa'naDa':n}. Its capital city is {qebeq veng:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of the province of {qebeq:n} in {qa'naDa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a state located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the transliteration of a brand of soft drink found on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a native Klingon word but a borrowing. For the disease (COVID-19), one could say {qo'vID wa'maH Hut:n:nolink}.[1]
Some people online have also taken to using the non-canon expression {mIv'a' javtIm:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a borrowing and not a native Klingon word.[1]
It is unclear why this doesn't follow the pattern of other Terran fruit names of using the borrowed word followed by {naH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the actress who plays B'Elanna Torres.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a major river in {'ewrop:n} which has its sources in {SuwISya':n} and flows through {DoyIchlan:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {'Italya':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a word borrowed from Federation Standard to refer to a specific Terran flower.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a place on Earth, and so is borrowed from Federation Standard.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a loanword from Federation Standard, and refers to a type of wind instrument.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a country on Earth. It should not be confused with {jorja:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city in {DoyIchlan:n} where the {qepHom'a':n} takes place.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the colloquial name for {Sol jav:n@@Sol:n, jav:n:1,num}, a planet in the {Sol:n} system. It does not follow proper Klingon phonology, since it is an alien name.
The tweet confirms that the translation was provided by MO.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a river in the {noghmanDIy:n} region of {vIraS:n}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a fruit originally from Earth. It is not referred to as {tera' tanje'rIn:n:nolink}.[2]
It is unclear why this doesn't follow the pattern of other Terran fruit names of using the borrowed word followed by {naH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a state located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}. Its capital city is {'oStIn:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a way to refer to the Earth disease, based on a misguided translation. See {tera' ghIch rop:n} and {tera' tlhuH rop:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a word borrowed from Federation Standard referring to an Earth plant.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}. It is treated as a single name and in normal conversation, the {DIySIy:sen:nolink} is never left off.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a country on Earth. Its capital city is {wa'SIngtanDIySIy:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a country on Earth. Not to be confused with the planet {'anDor:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a character in a series of Earth novels.
Jack Bradley translated the story The Wizard of Oz as {'aS 'IDnar pIn'a' Dun:sen@@'aS:n, 'IDnar pIn'a':n, Dun:v}, from whence came this name and a bunch of new vocabulary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a place name in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: Informally, people had been using {tulwI' Hol:n@@tul:v, -wI':v, Hol:n}, based on its literal meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Klingon pronunciation of the word "spade", referring to the suit in a deck of playing cards. For a (physical) shovel, see {ghevjur:n}.
In MO's message, he wrote "He [Maltz] just called a spade {'eSpeD:n:nolink}." The expression "calling a spade a spade" is an idiom in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the unit of European currency.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was accidentally left out of the continents section of the printed booklet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a river in {mIyama:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a word borrowed from Federation Standard to refer to the Terran animal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a state located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}. Its capital city is {'InDIyene'palIS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of the state of {'InDIye'na':n} in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Its capital city is {roma':n}.
To describe an "italics" font, {chongHa':v@@chong:v:1, -Ha':v} may be used.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the capital city of the state of {teqSaS:n} in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The reference in {Hamlet:src} is not to the Chancellor ({ghorqan:n:name}) who sought peace with the Federation, but to one of his legendary ancestors.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a famous play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of its eponymous protagonist.
This is written as "Khamlet" in the introductory text of {Hamlet:src}, but as "Hamlet" in the English side of the play itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: His original Klingon name was never spoken in {Star Trek VI:src}, where he was only referred to as "Shakespeare".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a famous Klingon playwright.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of its titular character, a legendary Romulan leader.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a form of ritualistic torture performed by Klingon women on prisoners of war.

This word and {norgh:n} first appeared in the novel {Sarek:src} by A. C. Crispin. Three years later, {norgh:n:nolink} appeared in {KGT:src}, but {be'joy':n:nolink} was left out, possibly to keep the book "family-friendly".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is said during the ritual of discommendation ({naDHa'ghach:n}). The usual way to say "coward" is {nuch:n}.

According to the script for {TNG - Sins of the Father:src}, Worf says {tlhIH ghIj jIHyoj:sen@@tlhIH:n, ghIj:v, jIH:n:1, yoj:n}, which is not grammatical, but is supposed to mean "I fear your judgment". K'mpec then replies with {bIHnuch:sen:nolink}. It is reasonable to assume that these two phrases are archaic and ritualised.
It's likely that these sentences were made up by a writer who consulted {TKD:src}, as they contain existing words, but did not have an understanding of Klingon grammar.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {Honor Bound:src}, this is an animal native to {bo'retlh:n}, which makes bleating sounds and tends to run around in circles.
This is closer to a hyena than a sheep, according to a {@KRADeC tweet 2012.07.02:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
{tlhIngan Hol boQwI':n:nolink} "Klingon Language Assistant" - database version [[VERSION]].
To begin searching, simply press the "Search" (magnifying glass) button and type into the search box.
To hear the sounds of Klingon, you need to install a {Text-To-Speech engine:url:https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.tlhInganHol.android.klingonttsengine}.
To chat with other Klingon speakers, join the {KLI Discord server:url:https://www.kli.org/activities/discord/}.
It is recommended to install the {Klingon Keyboard for ASK:url:https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.anysoftkeyboard.languagepack.tlhIngan}. Otherwise, to make it easier to type Klingon on a mobile keyboard, the following shorthand (called "xifan hol") can be enabled under the Preferences menu: c ▶ {ch:sen:nolink} / d ▶ {D:sen:nolink} / f ▶ {ng:sen:nolink} / g ▶ {gh:sen:nolink} / h ▶ {H:sen:nolink} / i ▶ {I:sen:nolink} / k ▶ {Q:sen:nolink} / s ▶ {S:sen:nolink} / x ▶ {tlh:sen:nolink} / z ▶ {':sen:nolink} It is also possible to choose the alternate keymapping: k ▶ {q:sen:nolink} / q ▶ {Q:sen:nolink}
If you encounter any problems, or have any suggestions, please send me an {email at De.vID.jonpIn@gmail.com:url:mailto:De.vID.jonpIn@gmail.com?subject=boQwI%27%20feedback&body=Device:%20%0D%0AAndroid%20version:%20%0D%0A}.
Please support the Klingon language by purchasing {The Klingon Dictionary:src}, {Klingon for the Galactic Traveler:src}, {The Klingon Way:src}, {Conversational Klingon:src}, {Power Klingon:src}, and other Klingon- and Star Trek-related products from Pocket Books, Simon & Schuster, and Paramount/Viacom/CBS Entertainment.
Klingon, Star Trek, and related marks are trademarks of CBS Studios, Inc., and are used under "fair use" guidelines.
Android programming: {De'vID:n:name} Flutter (iOS) port: Daniel Dadap Klingon-English data: {De'vID:n:name,nolink}, with help from others German translations: {Quvar:n:name} (Lieven L. Litaer) Swedish translations: {Klingonska Akademien:url:http://klingonska.org/} Russian translations: Кирилл Шилов, Дэниел Дэдеп and Sirglin (Ольга Косарева) Portuguese translations: Thiago Matos Finnish translations: Iikka Hauhio TNG {pIqaD:n} font: Admiral {qurgh lungqIj:n:name,nolink} of the {Klingon Assault Group:url:http://www.kag.org/} DSC {pIqaD:n:nolink} font: {Quvar:n:name,nolink} (Lieven L. Litaer)
Special thanks to Marc Okrand ({marq 'oqranD:n:name}) for creating the Klingon language.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a female in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of Captain Lorca's previous ship.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term doesn't appear in canon, but rather was invented for a blog post about science. It's here so that someone else doesn't invent a different term.
This term was coined by Felix Malmenbeck ({loghaD:n:nolink}), and roughly means "sky-crystal gunpowder".

table.name: mem
table.column: The element {chem:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {ghe'chem:n}, {HoSchem:n}, {peQchem:n}, {pIvchem:n}, {Surchem:n}, and {tlhamchem:n}.
In {TKDA:src}, {peQ chem:n:nolink} actually appears as two words (with a space).

table.name: mem
table.column: This was carried out by {mo'qay tuq:n} on {voq:n}, to transform him into Lt. Ash Tyler.
[1] {DSC - The War Without, The War Within:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the author of this program and the compiler of its lexicon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {bo'DIj:n} and {ghIpDIj:v}. Its homophony to {DIj:v:1} suggests that it describes two parties pitted against one another.

table.name: mem
table.column: Neither {SuD:v:1} nor {Doq:v} includes what is called "violet" or "purple". This may be related to Klingon physiology.[2]

Despite the statement in {KGT:src} that "violet" and "purple" are not covered by the Klingon colour words, it was nevertheless included in {TNK:src} as that software follows a fixed template which required a translation to label such a colour.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's likely that {Do':n:archaic,hyp,nolink} is an archaic word for the modern {Duj:n:1}.[1] This conjecture is supported by {'ejDo':n} and {Delaq Do':excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {nenghep:n} and {peHghep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: These are creatures bred by Klingons specifically to eat tribbles.[1]
[1] {TAS - More Tribbles, More Troubles:src}, [2] {How to Speak Klingon, p.4:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is described in the glossary to {A Burning House:src} as a game involving tokens and wagers.

table.name: mem
table.column: gin'tak, trusted adviser of a Klingon House
In {TNG - Firstborn:src}, K'mtar is the gin'tak to the House of Mogh.[1] In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, it is claimed that this word and {ghIntaq:n:1} are in fact the same word.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a vegetable usually served diced.

table.name: mem
table.column: The element {ghor:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {pIvghor:n} and {Hongghor:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a name used in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of stone indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} which is often used in the contruction of statuary.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a fruit grown on Klingon farms.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a hypothetical component that is found in {pemjep:n} and {ramjep:n:1}.
Maltz said he'd never heard {jarjep:n:nolink}, {DISjep:n:nolink}, {Hoghjep:n:nolink}, or the like, but would get the gist of what was meant if someone said it.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist by itself, but it is found in {jonpIn:n}, {jonta':n}, and {jonwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was invented by author David Mack, who said it can be assumed to be in an obscure older dialect.[2]
[1] {Star Trek Vanguard - Harbinger p.202:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2020.06.23:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This term is seen on a sign in a food stall, which Lt. Ash Tyler translated as "space whale". It refers to the {ghormaghenDer:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a female in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maktag, name of a month or season?
Alexander Rozhenko was born on the 43rd day of Maktag.
The Klingon way of writing this name was never given. The script only says "Maktag".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears in the {Star Trek - Prey:src} trilogy by John Jackson Miller. It is said to be an "old concept", in which rivals who ally in battle for a time celebrate a temporary truce after a successful joint action, before returning to hostilities.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears in the glossary to {Enemy Territory:src}, where it is described as a "sex aid". It is unclear as to whether it refers to a specific object, a class of objects, or even what it is in general.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this is a type of torpedo carried on the {bI'rel tlharghDuj:n} and {vorcha':n} classes of ships.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a hypothetical component that is found in {loDnal:n}, {be'nal:n}, {'e'nal:n} (and the words for various relatives by marriage), {nalqaD:n}, as well as {lIwnal:n}. According to {KCD:src}, {nal:n:hyp,nolink} is not used as a word on its own.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this is a kind of ordnance carried by a Bird of Prey ({toQDuj:n}) which can be deployed either as a short-range torpedo or as a mine distribution system.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this is the standard torpedo type carried on the Bird of Prey ({toQDuj:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Kinds of {pa'mey:n:nolink} include {yaS pa'mey:n}, {beq pa'mey:n}, and {mebpa'mey:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Triticale is a hybridization of wheat (genus Triticum) and rye (genus Secale). {pev:n:hyp,nolink} is not a known word, it is known only as an element in the word {loSpev:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the person in charge of a game of {tISang:n}.[1]
This word was not translated but was spoken by the players.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a known word, and exists as an element in the word {cha'puj:n} and possibly also in the word {beqpuj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This name is untranslated in {KGT:src}, and is possibly a misspelling for {qo'leq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a male in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word doesn't appear in canon, but rather was invented for a blog post about science. It's here so that someone else doesn't invent a different word.
This word was coined by Felix Malmenbeck ({loghaD:n:nolink}), and roughly means "hidden fire".

table.name: mem
table.column: It's possible that the writers intended this to be {Qu'vatlh:excl}, or based their invented word on it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word element appears to be synonymous with {DIvI':n}, but it is not known outside of a few compounds.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a small piece of text attached to something else, such as a post on a social network or a block of computer code.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the Klingon language expert behind the dialogue in {DSC:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Klingon name of Lieven L. Litaer, a {Klingon teacher from Germany:url:http://www.youtube.com/user/KlingonTeacher}.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary of {Enemy Territory:src}, this animal prefers the shadow.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was used in the Klingon-language subtitles for {DSC:src} on Netflix for the word "transponder" in spoken English dialogue.
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist outside of {yInroH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be agile, be nimble, be spry?
This verb is not known to exist, but its existence is conjectured based on the idiom {pe'vIl roS:sen:idiom} and the verb {roSHa'moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the {bI'rel tlharghDuj:n} commanded by {martaq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, it is hypothesized that this is an animal from or with whose blood {ro'qegh'Iwchab:n} are made.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz said he's never heard of a noun {SeH:n:nolink}, but that the {SeH:sen:nolink} in {SeHjan:n}, {SeHlaw:n}, and {'eDSeHcha:n} and elsewhere is clearly related to the verb {SeH:v}. Using {SeH:n:nolink} as an independent word (as a noun) felt weird to him (but he's changed his mind before).
This was revealed after the Q & A session in a document explaining the grammar of {bIQ SeHjan:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not known to exist outside of the compound {SIS yoD:n}.
MO said at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that the apparent noun {SIS:n:hyp,nolink} is a fossilized remnant which is probably limited to the expression {SIS yoD:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a typo for {Suq:v:nolink} which appeared in {HQ 6.2:src} in the transcription of {SkyBox 33:src}. The word is spelled correctly as {Suq:v:nolink} on the card itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: The gizzards of this animal, together with their contents, are sometimes served as food. The droppings of this animal are particularly foul-smelling.
[1] {A Good Day to Die:src}, [2] {A Burning House:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears on {KGT p.132:src}, but based on the context it is clearly a typo for {bIt:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The symbol of the Klingon Empire (the imperial trefoil) is said to be called the "Heart of Virtue", or {tIq'ghob:n:nolink} "in the ancient tongue" (see {no' Hol:n}), by General Chang ({cheng:n:name}). In modern standard Klingon, "Heart of Virtue" would be {ghob tIq:n:nolink}. The two words are transposed in the manner of {paq'batlh:n}.
The three arms of the {tIq'ghob:n:nolink} are said to represent honor, loyalty, and duty.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon board game played with dice. Its name means "obliterate them".[1]

This game was named after {DSC:src} graphic designer Andy Tsang. By coincidence, {tISang:n:nolink} happens to have an appropriate meaning in Klingon. This meaning was mentioned in the episode in which it appears.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a large animal native to {rura' pente':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was taken by the Klingon spy Lurqal who diguised herself as a Human female, to supplement the non-Klingon food she had to eat while undercover.
This was invented by author David Mack, who said it can be assumed to be in an obscure older dialect.[2]
[1] {Star Trek Vanguard - Harbinger p.200:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2020.06.23:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a male in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: You have entered the jurisdiction of the Klingon Empire.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a concept in computer programming, namely, a segment of code which is repeatedly executed until some condition is met.

This was used in Klingon Blockly. Marc Okrand was shown a list of terms and their translations, and commented that Maltz said that some of them were the correct terminology used by Klingons. However, it isn't clear which ones.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Since this is not a grammatical sentence, one can only assume that it is in some form of {no' Hol:n}. It is recommended to say {Qapla'!:sen} or {povjaj!:excl} instead.

This ungrammatical expression appears on the back cover of {How to Speak Klingon:src}, where it is translated as "Good luck".[1] Even though the sentences inside this book were provide by the Klingon Language Institute (see {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}) and use proper grammar, it seems that whoever designed the cover just copied this erroneous expression from the Internet without verifying it with a competent speaker. The originator of this expression is unknown but it appeared on some fan websites in 2011, where it is claimed that it literally means "Go with fortune".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used in the {ma'to'vor:n} ritual. It must be real and not replicated.[1]
[1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {A Good Day to Die:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: be landed? be in the air? (aircraft)

This is an unknown element found in {'eDSeHcha:n}. Following the example of {lolSeHcha:n}, this should be a verb related to aircraft landing or take-off. Perhaps it is the same word as {'eD:v:1} and taking off or landing is somehow related to crawling in the Klingon way of thinking.

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is known only from {'ejDo':n} and {'ejyo':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Terran name used in the Duolingo Klingon course.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {'ISletlh:n:hyp,nolink} has never appeared by itself, but is found in {yan 'ISletlh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the translator of the Tao Te Ching and Sunzi's Art of War into Klingon.
